metadata.case_name: Mst. Kharbuja Kuer v. Jangbahadur Rai & Ors.

facts.text: Genealogy: Ramlal Rai had sons Jamuna Rai (deceased), Jangbahadur Rai (D1), Rameshwar Rai (deceased, husband of plaintiff Mst. Kharbuja Kuer), and Kasida Kuer (deceased). Rameshwar's brothers: Jugeshar Rai (D2), Rambirchh Rai (D3), Mahessar Rai (D4).
Rameshwar Rai and Jangbahadur Rai (D1) effected a partition of family property in or about 1924. Rameshwar in exclusive possession of his share thereafter.
Rameshwar Rai died in 1930. Plaintiff (widow) and mother-in-law continued in possession.
D1 asked plaintiff and mother-in-law to execute power of attorney. They, being pardanashin ladies, executed document on August 24, 1935, believing it to be power of attorney.
Document was maintenance deed with false recitals of no separation and joint family property. Not read out to them; scribe and attesting witnesses partisans of D1. Always in D1's custody.
Plaintiff and mother-in-law continued getting income from property as before execution till mother-in-law's death.
Fraud discovered in 1355 fasli when D1 interfered with possession, claimed only maintenance right, and plaintiff got document read.
Plaintiff filed suit in Munsif, Muzaffarpur, for declaration of title and that maintenance deed fraudulent and not binding.
Defendants denied fraud; alleged deed read and explained, Babu Ramnath Singh (plaintiff's brother) present and signed on her behalf.

Issues framed: No.3 - Separation between Rameshwar and D1 in Asardh 1334 Fs. (1927)? No.4 - Document dated 24-8-1935 valid and read over? No.5 - Entitled to reliefs? Burden on plaintiff for separation, on defendant for document knowledge.
Munsif found separation, pardanashin ladies ignorant with confidence in D1, document not read/understood; decreed suit.
Subordinate Judge confirmed findings and decree on appeal.
Patna HC (Imam J.) reversed on second appeal: Burden wrongly placed; plaintiff failed to prove fraud; dismissed suit. Dated December 2, 1957, in S.A. No. 791 of 1963.
Plaintiff and mother-in-law pardanashin, illiterate (one old, one middle-aged), full confidence in D1.
Babu Ramnath Singh not proved brother; document in D1 custody; no examination of key witnesses by D1.

legal_issues.text: Is the allegation of separation between Rameshwar Rai and defendant No. 1 in the month of Asardh 1334 Fs. correct?
Is the document dated 24-8-1935 legal and valid? Was the same read over to the plaintiff and executed with full knowledge of contents?
Are the plaintiffs entitled to the reliefs claimed?
Who bears the burden of proof regarding execution of document by pardanashin lady?

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court wrong on burden of proof; Munsif and Sub Judge correctly placed burden on defendant and gave findings on entire evidence; findings of fact binding under s.100 CPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S. 100 Code of Civil Procedure; law on pardanashin ladies

respondent_arguments.text: Finding on separation halting, illegal, not based on evidence; initial burden on defendant discharged by evidence and circumstances.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Presumption of jointness under Hindu law

respondent_arguments.text: Question of separation irrelevant; both parties agreed not necessary.

court_reasoning.text: High Court has no jurisdiction in second appeal on erroneous finding of fact unless vitiated by law error.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Concurrent findings of Munsif and Sub Judge binding.

court_reasoning.text: Pardanashin ladies get special protection; burden on person seeking to sustain document to prove it was executed after clear understanding (physical and mental act), not only by explanation but by circumstances.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rule distinct from fraud/duress; Privy Council principles.

court_reasoning.text: Lower courts approached correctly, concurrent finding defendant failed to discharge burden; even apart, facts support plaintiff ignorant of contents.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court wrongly shifted burden to plaintiff.

court_reasoning.text: Separation finding based on oral, documentary, circumstantial evidence; relevant to probability of executing document admitting jointness.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Binding on High Court; rebuts jointness presumption.

court_reasoning.text: Facts supporting finding: pardanashin/illiterate, confidence in D1, disputed witnesses, custody with D1, continued possession, no key witnesses examined.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No ground to interfere in second appeal.

holdings.text: Burden of proof rests on person seeking to sustain transaction with pardanashin lady to establish execution after understanding nature.
Concurrent findings of fact by lower courts not interferable by High Court in second appeal.
Document not binding; plaintiff entitled to declaration of title.

precedents_cited.relevance: Origin and principle of protection for pardanashin ladies; burden to show free and intelligent act from circumstances.

precedents_cited.case_name: Geresh Chunder Lahoree v. Mst. Bhuggobutty Debia
precedents_cited.relevance: Court to ascertain pardanashin woman was free agent and informed.
Burden on those founding on deed to show affirmatively explained and understood.
Reiterated burden discharge by circumstances, not only explanation.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court no jurisdiction to interfere with concurrent findings of fact in second appeal.

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Law
statutes_cited.relevance: Presumption of joint family rebutted by evidence of partition.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Patna High Court judgment set aside; decree of Munsif and Subordinate Judge restored declaring maintenance deed fraudulent and not binding, confirming plaintiff's title.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration of title to suit property; maintenance deed declared fraudulent and not binding.

key_quotes.text: The burden of proof shall always rest upon the person who seeks to sustain a transaction entered into with a pardanashin lady to establish that the said document was executed by her after clearly understanding the nature of the transaction.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on burden of proof for pardanashin ladies.

key_quotes.text: In India pardanashin ladies have been given a special protection in view of the social conditions of the time, they are presumed to have an imperfect knowledge of the world.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It demands that the burden of proof shall in such a case rest, not with those who attack, but with those who found upon the deed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Privy Council on shifting burden.
